+

 Accessing entities defined in another namespace
 -----------------------------------------------
 
-These entities can be accessed in Owlready2 using a namespace. The .get_namepace(base_iri) method of an ontology
+These entities can be accessed in Owlready2 using a namespace. The get_namepace(base_iri) global function
 returns a namespace for the given base IRI.
 
 The namespace can then be used with the dot notation, similarly to the ontology.
 
 ::
    
    >>> # Loads Gene Ontology (~ 170 Mb), can take a moment!
    >>> go = get_ontology("http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/go.owl").load()
    
    >>> print(go.GO_0000001) # Not in the right namespace

-   >>> obo = go.get_namespace("http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/")
+   >>> obo = get_namespace("http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/")
    
    >>> print(obo.GO_0000001)
    obo.GO_0000001
    
    >>> print(obo.GO_0000001.iri)
    http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/obo.GO_0000001
    
    >>> print(obo.GO_0000001.label)
    ['mitochondrion inheritance']
 
+   
+.get_namepace(base_iri) can also be called on an Ontology, for example:
+
+::
+   
+   >>> obo = go.get_namespace("http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/")
+
+Namespaces created on an Ontology can also be used for asserting facts and creating classes, instances,...:
 
+::
+
+   >>> with obo:
+   >>>     class MyNewClass(Thing): pass # Create http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/MyNewClass
+   
 
 Creating classes in a specific namespace
 ----------------------------------------
 
 When creating a Class or a Property,
 the namespace attribute is used to build the full IRI of the Class,
 and to define in which ontology the Class is defined

 *************************************
 
 Owlready2 is a package for ontology-oriented programming in Python. It can load OWL 2.0 ontologies
 as Python objects, modify them, save them, and perform reasoning via HermiT
 (included). Owlready2 allows a transparent access to OWL ontologies (contrary
 to usual Java-based API).
 
-Owlready version 2 includes an optimized triplestore / quadstore, based on SQLite3.
+Owlready version 2 includes an optimized triplestore / quadstore, based on SQLite3 or PostgresQL.
 This quadstore is optimized both for performance and memory consumption. Controray to version 1,
 Owlready2 can deal with big ontologies.
 
 Owlready2 has been created at the LIMICS reseach lab,
 University Paris 13, Sorbonne Paris Cit, INSERM UMRS 1142, Paris 6 University, by
 Jean-Baptiste Lamy. It was developed during the VIIIP research project funded by ANSM, the French Drug Agency;
 this is why some examples in this documentation relate to drug ;).

 Worlds
 ======
 
 Owlready2 stores every triples in a 'World' object, and it can handles several Worlds
 in parallel. 'default_world' is the World used by default.
 
 
-Persistent world: storing the quadstore in an SQLite3 file
-----------------------------------------------------------
+Persistent world: storing the quadstore in an SQLite3 file database
+-------------------------------------------------------------------
 
 Owlready2 uses an optimized quadstore. By default, the quadstore is stored in memory, but it can also be
 stored in an SQLite3 file. This allows persistance: all ontologies loaded and created are stored in the file,
 and can be reused later.
 This is interesting for big ontogolies: loading huge ontologies can take time, while opening the SQLite3 file
 takes only a fraction of second, even for big files.
 It also avoid to load huge ontologies in memory, if you only need to access a few
@@ -35,14 +35,39 @@
 ::
 
    >>> default_world.save()
 
 Storing the quadstore in a file does not reduce the performance of Owlready2 (actually,
 it seems that Owlready2 performs a little *faster* when storing the quadstore on the disk).
 
+By default, Owlready2 opens the SQLite3 database in exclusive mode. This mode is faster, but it does not allow
+several programs to use the same database simultaneously. If you need to have several Python programs that
+access simultaneously the same Owlready2 quadstore, you can disable the exclusive mode as follows:
+
+::
+
+   >>> default_world.set_backend(filename = "/path/to/your/file.sqlite3", exclusive = False)
+
+
+
+Persistent world: storing the quadstore in a PostgresQL database
+----------------------------------------------------------------
+
+PostgresQL can be used as an alternative to SQLite3. However, the the interest is limited since performances are lower.
+
+To use a PostgresQL database, you first need to create the database (using the createdb command).
+
+Then, you can set the PostgresQL backend as follows:
+
+::
+
+   >>> default_world.set_backend("postgresql", user = "USERNAME", password = "PASS", dbname = "DATABASE_NAME", host = "HOST", port = PORT)
+
+
+
 
 Using several isolated Worlds
 -----------------------------
 
 Owlready2 can support several, isolated, Worlds.
 This is interesting if you want to load several version
 of the same ontology, for example before and after reasoning.

 <h1>Namespaces<a class="headerlink" href="#namespaces" title="Permalink to this headline"></a></h1>
 <p>Ontologies can define entities located in other namespaces.
 An example is Gene Ontology (GO): the ontology IRI is <a class="reference external" href="http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/go.owl">http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/go.owl</a>,
 but the IRI of GO entities are not of the form <a class="reference external" href="http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/go.owl#GO_entity">http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/go.owl#GO_entity</a> but
 <a class="reference external" href="http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/GO_entity">http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/GO_entity</a> (note the missing go.owl#).</p>
 <div class="section" id="accessing-entities-defined-in-another-namespace">
 <h2>Accessing entities defined in another namespace<a class="headerlink" href="#accessing-entities-defined-in-another-namespace" title="Permalink to this headline"></a></h2>
-<p>These entities can be accessed in Owlready2 using a namespace. The .get_namepace(base_iri) method of an ontology
+<p>These entities can be accessed in Owlready2 using a namespace. The get_namepace(base_iri) global function
 returns a namespace for the given base IRI.</p>
 <p>The namespace can then be used with the dot notation, similarly to the ontology.</p>
 <div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="gp">&gt;&gt;&gt; </span><span class="c1"># Loads Gene Ontology (~ 170 Mb), can take a moment!</span>
 <span class="gp">&gt;&gt;&gt; </span><span class="n">go</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">get_ontology</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">&quot;http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/go.owl&quot;</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">load</span><span class="p">()</span>
 
 <span class="gp">&gt;&gt;&gt; </span><span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">go</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">GO_0000001</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="c1"># Not in the right namespace</span>
 <span class="go">None</span>
 
-<span class="gp">&gt;&gt;&gt; </span><span class="n">obo</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">go</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">get_namespace</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">&quot;http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/&quot;</span><span class="p">)</span>
+<span class="gp">&gt;&gt;&gt; </span><span class="n">obo</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">get_namespace</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">&quot;http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/&quot;</span><span class="p">)</span>
 
 <span class="gp">&gt;&gt;&gt; </span><span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">obo</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">GO_0000001</span><span class="p">)</span>
 <span class="go">obo.GO_0000001</span>
 
 <span class="gp">&gt;&gt;&gt; </span><span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">obo</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">GO_0000001</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">iri</span><span class="p">)</span>
 <span class="go">http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/obo.GO_0000001</span>
 
 <span class="gp">&gt;&gt;&gt; </span><span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">obo</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">GO_0000001</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">label</span><span class="p">)</span>
 <span class="go">[&#39;mitochondrion inheritance&#39;]</span>
 </pre></div>
 </div>
+<p>.get_namepace(base_iri) can also be called on an Ontology, for example:</p>
+<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="gp">&gt;&gt;&gt; </span><span class="n">obo</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">go</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">get_namespace</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">&quot;http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/&quot;</span><span class="p">)</span>
+</pre></div>
+</div>
+<p>Namespaces created on an Ontology can also be used for asserting facts and creating classes, instances,:</p>
+<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="gp">&gt;&gt;&gt; </span><span class="k">with</span> <span class="n">obo</span><span class="p">:</span>
+<span class="gp">&gt;&gt;&gt; </span>    <span class="k">class</span> <span class="nc">MyNewClass</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">Thing</span><span class="p">):</span> <span class="k">pass</span> <span class="c1"># Create http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/MyNewClass</span>
+</pre></div>
+</div>

 *************************************
 
 Owlready2 is a package for ontology-oriented programming in Python. It can load OWL 2.0 ontologies
 as Python objects, modify them, save them, and perform reasoning via HermiT
 (included). Owlready2 allows a transparent access to OWL ontologies (contrary
 to usual Java-based API).

+Owlready version 2 includes an optimized triplestore / quadstore, based on SQLite3 or PostgresQL.
 This quadstore is optimized both for performance and memory consumption. Controray to version 1,
 Owlready2 can deal with big ontologies.
 
 Owlready2 has been created at the LIMICS reseach lab,
 University Paris 13, Sorbonne Paris Cit, INSERM UMRS 1142, Paris 6 University, by
 Jean-Baptiste Lamy. It was developed during the VIIIP research project funded by ANSM, the French Drug Agency;

 Worlds
 ======
 
 Owlready2 stores every triples in a 'World' object, and it can handles several Worlds
 in parallel. 'default_world' is the World used by default.
 
 
-Persistent world: storing the quadstore in an SQLite3 file
-----------------------------------------------------------
+Persistent world: storing the quadstore in an SQLite3 file database
+-------------------------------------------------------------------
 
 Owlready2 uses an optimized quadstore. By default, the quadstore is stored in memory, but it can also be
 stored in an SQLite3 file. This allows persistance: all ontologies loaded and created are stored in the file,
 and can be reused later.
 This is interesting for big ontogolies: loading huge ontologies can take time, while opening the SQLite3 file
 takes only a fraction of second, even for big files.
 It also avoid to load huge ontologies in memory, if you only need to access a few
@@ -35,14 +35,39 @@
 ::
 
    >>> default_world.save()
 
 Storing the quadstore in a file does not reduce the performance of Owlready2 (actually,
 it seems that Owlready2 performs a little *faster* when storing the quadstore on the disk).
 
+By default, Owlready2 opens the SQLite3 database in exclusive mode. This mode is faster, but it does not allow
+several programs to use the same database simultaneously. If you need to have several Python programs that
+access simultaneously the same Owlready2 quadstore, you can disable the exclusive mode as follows:
+
+::
+
+   >>> default_world.set_backend(filename = "/path/to/your/file.sqlite3", exclusive = False)
+
+
+
+Persistent world: storing the quadstore in a PostgresQL database
+----------------------------------------------------------------
+
+PostgresQL can be used as an alternative to SQLite3. However, the the interest is limited since performances are lower.
+
+To use a PostgresQL database, you first need to create the database (using the createdb command).
+
+Then, you can set the PostgresQL backend as follows:
+
+::
+
+   >>> default_world.set_backend("postgresql", user = "USERNAME", password = "PASS", dbname = "DATABASE_NAME", host = "HOST", port = PORT)
+
+
+
 
 Using several isolated Worlds
 -----------------------------
 
 Owlready2 can support several, isolated, Worlds.
 This is interesting if you want to load several version
 of the same ontology, for example before and after reasoning.

 Owlready2 is a package for manipulating OWL 2.0 ontologies in Python. It can
 load, modify, save ontologies, and it supports reasoning via HermiT (included).
 Owlready allows a transparent access to OWL ontologies.
 Owlready2 can:
          * Import ontologies in RDF/XML, OWL/XML or NTriples format.
          * Manipulates ontology classes, instances and annotations as if
            they were Python objects.
          * Add Python methods to ontology classes.
          * Re-classify instances automatically, using the HermiT reasoner.
+If you need to convert formulas between Protg, Owlready2 and/or Description
+Logics, the following cheat sheet may be of interest:

   <div class="section" id="worlds">
 <h1>Worlds<a class="headerlink" href="#worlds" title="Permalink to this headline"></a></h1>
 <p>Owlready2 stores every triples in a World object, and it can handles several Worlds
 in parallel. default_world is the World used by default.</p>
-<div class="section" id="persistent-world-storing-the-quadstore-in-an-sqlite3-file">
-<h2>Persistent world: storing the quadstore in an SQLite3 file<a class="headerlink" href="#persistent-world-storing-the-quadstore-in-an-sqlite3-file" title="Permalink to this headline"></a></h2>
+<div class="section" id="persistent-world-storing-the-quadstore-in-an-sqlite3-file-database">
+<h2>Persistent world: storing the quadstore in an SQLite3 file database<a class="headerlink" href="#persistent-world-storing-the-quadstore-in-an-sqlite3-file-database" title="Permalink to this headline"></a></h2>
 <p>Owlready2 uses an optimized quadstore. By default, the quadstore is stored in memory, but it can also be
 stored in an SQLite3 file. This allows persistance: all ontologies loaded and created are stored in the file,
 and can be reused later.
 This is interesting for big ontogolies: loading huge ontologies can take time, while opening the SQLite3 file
 takes only a fraction of second, even for big files.
 It also avoid to load huge ontologies in memory, if you only need to access a few
 entities from these ontologies.</p>
@@ -68,14 +68,29 @@
 <p>When using persistence, the .save() method of World must be called for saving the actual
 state of the quadstore in the SQLite3 file:</p>
 <div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="gp">&gt;&gt;&gt; </span><span class="n">default_world</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">save</span><span class="p">()</span>
 </pre></div>
 </div>
 <p>Storing the quadstore in a file does not reduce the performance of Owlready2 (actually,
 it seems that Owlready2 performs a little <em>faster</em> when storing the quadstore on the disk).</p>
+<p>By default, Owlready2 opens the SQLite3 database in exclusive mode. This mode is faster, but it does not allow
+several programs to use the same database simultaneously. If you need to have several Python programs that
+access simultaneously the same Owlready2 quadstore, you can disable the exclusive mode as follows:</p>
+<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="gp">&gt;&gt;&gt; </span><span class="n">default_world</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">set_backend</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">filename</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s2">&quot;/path/to/your/file.sqlite3&quot;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">exclusive</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kc">False</span><span class="p">)</span>
+</pre></div>
+</div>
+</div>
+<div class="section" id="persistent-world-storing-the-quadstore-in-a-postgresql-database">
+<h2>Persistent world: storing the quadstore in a PostgresQL database<a class="headerlink" href="#persistent-world-storing-the-quadstore-in-a-postgresql-database" title="Permalink to this headline"></a></h2>
+<p>PostgresQL can be used as an alternative to SQLite3. However, the the interest is limited since performances are lower.</p>
+<p>To use a PostgresQL database, you first need to create the database (using the createdb command).</p>
+<p>Then, you can set the PostgresQL backend as follows:</p>
+<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="gp">&gt;&gt;&gt; </span><span class="n">default_world</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">set_backend</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">&quot;postgresql&quot;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">user</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s2">&quot;USERNAME&quot;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">password</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s2">&quot;PASS&quot;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">dbname</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s2">&quot;DATABASE_NAME&quot;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">host</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s2">&quot;HOST&quot;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">port</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">PORT</span><span class="p">)</span>
+</pre></div>
+</div>
 </div>

 Owlready2 uses an optimized quadstore. By default, the quadstore is stored in
 memory, but it can also be stored in an SQLite3 file. This allows persistance:
 all ontologies loaded and created are stored in the file, and can be reused
 later. This is interesting for big ontogolies: loading huge ontologies can take
 time, while opening the SQLite3 file takes only a fraction of second, even for
 big files. It also avoid to load huge ontologies in memory, if you only need to
 access a few entities from these ontologies.

 <h1>Welcome to Owlready2s documentation!<a class="headerlink" href="#welcome-to-owlready2-s-documentation" title="Permalink to this headline"></a></h1>
 <p>Owlready2 is a package for ontology-oriented programming in Python. It can load OWL 2.0 ontologies
 as Python objects, modify them, save them, and perform reasoning via HermiT
 (included). Owlready2 allows a transparent access to OWL ontologies (contrary
 to usual Java-based API).</p>
-<p>Owlready version 2 includes an optimized triplestore / quadstore, based on SQLite3.
+<p>Owlready version 2 includes an optimized triplestore / quadstore, based on SQLite3 or PostgresQL.
 This quadstore is optimized both for performance and memory consumption. Controray to version 1,
 Owlready2 can deal with big ontologies.</p>
 <p>Owlready2 has been created at the LIMICS reseach lab,
 University Paris 13, Sorbonne Paris Cit, INSERM UMRS 1142, Paris 6 University, by
 Jean-Baptiste Lamy. It was developed during the VIIIP research project funded by ANSM, the French Drug Agency;
 this is why some examples in this documentation relate to drug ;).</p>
 <p>Owlready2 is available under the GNU LGPL licence v3.
